sections.title: Common Questions
content: Q: What's the difference between mass and weight? Mass is the amount of matter in an object (measured in kg or lb), while weight is the force of gravity on that mass. In everyday use, we use them interchangeably. On Earth, 1 kg of mass weighs 1 kg, but on the Moon, that same mass would weigh only about 1/6th as much due to lower gravity.

Q: Why do recipes use both weight and volume measurements? Weight (grams, ounces) is more accurate than volume (cups, tablespoons), especially for baking. Professional bakers use weight exclusively. For example, 1 cup of flour can vary by 30+ grams depending on how you scoop it, but 125g of flour is always exactly 125g.

Q: How accurate do my measurements need to be for cooking? For most cooking, Â±5% accuracy is fine. For baking (especially bread and pastries), aim for Â±2% accuracy as chemical reactions are sensitive. For molecular gastronomy or pharmaceutical work, you need Â±0.1% or better.

Q: What's a 'stone' and why do some countries use it? A stone is 14 pounds (6.35 kg), commonly used in the UK and Ireland for measuring body weight. It originated from using standardized stones for weighing goods in markets. A person might say 'I weigh 11 stone' meaning 154 pounds or 70 kg.

Q: Can I use this for shipping weight calculations? Yes! Our converter is perfect for calculating shipping weights when freight companies use different units. Always round UP to the nearest whole unit for shipping quotes to avoid underestimating costs.
